content: Under the Impoundment Control Act of 1974, the President can propose to rescind funding from an appropriations act by sending a special message to Congress. If Congress does not approve the rescission within 45 days, the funding must be made available for executive agencies. President George W. Bush advocated for similar authority as Governor of Texas. President George W. Bush advocated for the item veto as Governor of Texas and later as President, pushing for the Legislative Line Item Veto Act of 2006 to address excessive earmark projects. The proposed expedited rescission process aimed to prevent Congress from ignoring presidential recommendations for funding cuts. The Legislative Line Item Veto Act of 2006 (LLIVA) was introduced to Congress on March 6, 2006, proposing expedited rescission to require a vote by at least one house on presidential funding cut recommendations. Enhanced rescission, previously available under the Line Item Veto Act of 1996, favored the President in spending reductions. The Line Item Veto Act of 1996 introduced "enhanced rescission," which favored the President in spending reductions by creating a presumption in their favor. Under this framework, spending cuts identified in special presidential messages would remain permanently cancelled unless Congress enacted a disapproval bill. If the President vetoed the disapproval bill, a two-thirds majority in both chambers would be needed to override the veto. Expedited rescission bills focus on procedural changes in Congress to ensure immediate consideration of the President's rescission request. Expedited rescission bills aim to streamline the process of approving the President's spending cuts by implementing fast-track procedures in Congress. This approach requires congressional approval to rescind funding but encourages a prompt up-or-down vote on the President's proposal.
